1. Ensure that default python is python3. In sonic-mgmt docker container, default python is python2. You can run
 the check by activating the python3 virtual environment in sonic-mgmt docker container or outside of sonic-mgmt
 docker container.
2. Ensure that the `pre-commit` package is installed:
```
sudo pip install pre-commit
```
3. Go to repository root folder
4. Install the pre-commit hooks:
```
pre-commit install
```
5. Use pre-commit to check staged file:
```
pre-commit
```
6. Alternatively, you can check committed files using:
```
pre-commit run --from-ref <commit_id> --to-ref <commit_id>
```

hi @bingwang-ms would you help to review?
Hi @vivekverma-arista, can you please help me understand why we need this change? Because the QoS parameter is per topo, and we already have that parameter defined for topo dualtor.

> Hi @vivekverma-arista, can you please help me understand why we need this change? Because the QoS parameter is per topo, and we already have that parameter defined for topo dualtor.

Hi @bingwang-ms, the parameters are per topo, the parameters are present for dualtor and dualtor-56, and there should be a separate section for dualtor-aa/dualtor-mixed. In the current state the test defaults to topo-any since there is no section for dualtor-aa: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/qos/tunnel_qos_remap_base.py#L297-L301. And under topo-any these values are not present, therefore it hits the key error.

Also the test is suppose to run in active-standby mode ( even in active-active dualtor ) as it's testing tunnel_qos_remap functionality so the same parameters should be used for dualtor/dualtor-aa/dualtor-mixed for a given cable length and speed. Hence the values in this change are same as: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/qos/files/qos_params.td3.yaml#L173-L202 which are being used for dualtor.

Hi @vivekverma-arista , may I know what's topo are you running the test on? I got your point, but I think adding the parameter into `topo-any` may not be good enough. Why not add a new section for the new topology?

> Hi @vivekverma-arista , may I know what's topo are you running the test on? I got your point, but I think adding the parameter into `topo-any` may not be good enough. Why not add a new section for the new topology?

The change is good for now because we only have one dualtor-aa topo. We need to add sections for different dualtor-aa topos probably in the future,

Did a little research on the history of this original tetcase:
https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/commit/259f540966d3e0a43bf9fc5c46360b1c3268e452
which I am copying it here:
```
[test gap] Add memory exhaustion test (https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/pull/5260)
What is the motivation for this PR?
Fix https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/issues/3619 
Validate kernel will panic and reboot the DUT when kernel runs out of memory and hit oom event.

How did you do it?
Use tail /dev/zero to run out of memory completely and check the DUT reboot as expected.

How did you verify/test it?
Run tests on vSONiC and physical DUTs.

Signed-off-by: Zhijian Li <zhijianli@microsoft.com>
```
Which indicate that the main purpose was to cause run out of the memory an expect that the Kernel to hit oom event to reboot the DUT.

Given that the Kernel tries very hard to "survive" when running low on memory, it becomes harder to kill it even with the "tail /dev/zero" where Kernel tries to "survive" by utilize the disk space more in low memory condition and takes a lot longer to get killed. This may be easier for some platform while some other platforms may linger longer for the "slow death". This PR's change is to "assist" the platform condition by not allowing disk swap as a way to reduce the kernel from surviving longer which I think still fits to what this testcase is trying to verify. Alternatively, is to lengthen the time expecting that the DUT to crash to longer time. I feel either method is good as a way to address this flaky testcase issue while ensure that the test still meets the original test intent. With this in mind, can community please review and see if this change is ok to take in?
Thanks!

Looks okay to me. Thanks @gechiang for the background

Adding my comment again, as the previous one is showing as Pending..

Instead of _datetime_ as deciding factor for seed and keeping modulo value as 15, we followed a **deterministic** approach based on the number of test ports for seed/modulo.

Due to this change based on test ports, irrespective of topology, all the time **at least two ports** would be selected for the test.

For example, currently with existing datetime approach, in case of T2, all the time, the number of selected ports is always one even with 16 test ports.

> @judyjoseph , Are you talking about the Queues assigned for these control packets received on front panel port? OR CPU?. Could you elaborate more?

I was referring to the earlier comment from Vineet -- that all the control packets should come in queue 7 irrespective of whether it is send out of CPU port or from front panel port. We can find out the behavior we observe and talk to broadcom if that is different from what was expected.

@judyjoseph , As i mentioned in the chat, the control packets received on front panel ports are queued based on the .1p or dscp values based on the packet type. SInce BGP packets are ip packets, it goes to Queue 0 based on the DSCP value. Since LLDP and LACP packets are untagged L2 packets, they are going to Queue 0. If this behavior is different from XGS, we need to check with BCM.
Following up with brcm via CS00012316603
In this PR, you're modifying it for PG7, and not queue7 right? Please update the title if indeed PG7 is being checked here.
@ansrajpu-git @saksarav-nokia we may need to update this PR to accommodate extra packets coming in on PG3/4 as we are not planning to change copp_cfg file to force all control packets to go to PG7.
@ansrajpu-git, Since we don't plan to add any changes in this. lets close this.

> @ansrajpu-git, Since we don't plan to add any changes in this. lets close this.

@vmittal-msft , The control packets sent from CPU are assigned to PG 7 of the port to which the control packet is sent out. The reason for this is that when CPU sends the packet out, it is sent via KNET which adds the PTCH header for DNX asic to understand the source port and the source system port is the port to which the control packet is sent out. since we send the control packets to TC=7, the tx control packets will be counted against PG 7 of the front panel port. I am checking with BCM to see why it is designed this way. If they can't fix it, then we need this PR.

@vmittal-msft , BCM confirmed in csp CS00012333616 that the control packets sent from CPU to the dest port will be mapped to the PG 7( PG mapped to sai_default_cpu_tx_tc=7) of the dest port since the packets sent from CPU are KNET using PTCH header. So we need to merge this PR.
